newsitem.title: USA: U.S. CREDIT OUTLOOK -- PPI seen steady on Thursday.
newsitem.headline: U.S. CREDIT OUTLOOK -- PPI seen steady on Thursday.

text.p: A data-starved U.S. government securities market prepared for release of the Producer Price Index on Thursday following a steep runoff late Wednesday.
The report was to released by the Labor Department at 0830 EST/1330 GMT.

A group of economists surveyed by Reuters expected, on average, that the overall PPI rate would rise 0.3 percent and the core rate -- excluding the volatile food and energy components -- by 0.1 percent.
Both estimates were similar to November levels.
Lynn Reaser, chief economist with Barnett Bank Inc, said higher energy costs had already been factored into most estimates.
"If the numbers come above consensus, we'll see more selloffs," Reaser said. "Otherwise the market will just wait for the payrolls number."
The Labor Department was set to release the December nonfarm payrolls report at 0830 EST/1330 GMT on Friday.
She said the bond market remained vulnerable, however, noting recent signs of renewed U.S. economic strength following relatively subdued third quarter growth.
"Unless PPI is a big surprise, I don't expect the market to move sharply either way ahead of payrolls data on Friday," said Hugh Johnson, economist with First Albany Corp.

Traders warned that many institutional investors have positioned for steady PPI figures and unexpected movements in either direction could cause a great deal of confusion before the more important payrolls report.

"If the core PPI rate break above 0.3 percent, we could get a scare," said Matt Alexy, chief market strategist with Credit Suisse First Boston. "But we think it will remain in forecasts and trading should stay in a range."
Alexy said real fear of inflation does not creep into the market until higher energy costs begin to become evident in the final products sector.
"When we have inflation numbers in the form of labor market tightness and earnings growth, that's when the market becomes concerned and that's why the payrolls report is so important," Alexy said.
Analysts expected that energy costs led by gasoline and fuel oil jumped about 2.0 percent, but should become a concern only when increases are passed along to crude and intermediate goods.

Also slated for release Thursday at 1000 EST/1500 GMT was the wholesale inventories November reading. Economists polled by Reuters expected, on average, the level would rise 0.2 percent versus a 0.6 percent increase in October.
In addition, several Federal Reserve policymakers were scheduled to make speeches throughout the country. Of late, most such comments have been considered fairly tame.

The Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee next meets on February 4 and 5, but few analysts expect any tightening move at that meeting. Instead, many see one coming at the FOMC's March meeting.
In late trading Wednesday the 30-year bond was down 21/32 at 95-20/32 to yield 6.84 percent.

The two-year note was at 99-17/32 to yield 6.00 percent, down 2/32. The five-year note was down 7/32 at 99-1/32 to yield 6.35 percent, while the 10-year note was at 99-09/32, down 12/32, to yield 6.61 percent.
Federal funds closed at 5-13/16 versus the Federal Reserve's current target level of 5.25 percent and were expected to open trade Thursday between 5-13/16 and 5.25 percent.
